Authors:
VINEET VISHAL, SOMNATH SINGH MUNDA, GEETANJALI Singh,
SHALINI LAL
Title:
Identification and molecular characterization of wild edible
mushroom Astraeus asiaticus from India Â– a first report
Keywords:
Boletales; Exoperidium; Jharkhand; India; Mushrooms;
Saranda Reserve Forest
Abstract:
The taxon Astraeus belongs to Order Boletales of Division
Basidiomycota and plays a multitude of ecological roles through
formation of mycorrhizal symbiosis with trees and shrubs by decomposing
wood and leaf litter. Owing to high nutritional property, it serves as
an important source of food and sold in local markets during monsoon.
Present work of identification of Astraeus species was carried out in
Saranda Reserve Forest (also an elephant corridor), West Singhbhum,
Jharkhand. The wild edible mushroom Astraeus asiaticus is partly buried
in ultisols in dry deciduous Dipterocarpus forest of Shorea robusta
Gaertn. This wild mushroom is found as solitary or scattered in small
groups of 2-4. It can be distinguished from allied taxa by hygroscopic
nature of exoperidium with 8 acute exoperidial rays, thickness of
peridium, glebal colour and spore morphology. The identification of wild
edible mushroom Astraeus asiaticus was established on the basis of its
morpho-anatomical features, molecular characterization which includes
comparison of sequence of ITS region of ribosomal DNA and phylogenetic
analysis. Till date, only two species of Astraeus have been reported
from India viz, A. hygrometricus and A. odoratus thus making it the
first report of Astraeus asiaticus from India.
